question: Who is the author of the letter of Jude, as identified in the first verse? (Jude 1:1)
choice: A servant of Jesus Christ and brother of James
A disciple of Jesus Christ
An apostle of Jesus Christ
A follower of the teachings of James

question: To whom is the letter of Jude addressed? (Jude 1:1)
choice: Those who are called, sanctified by God the Father, and kept for Jesus Christ
The churches in Galatia
The elders of Jerusalem
The Roman authorities

question: What does Jude desire for the recipients of his letter? (Jude 1:2)
choice: That mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to them
That their faith would be increased
That they would be given wealth
That they would be protected from their enemies

question: What was Jude initially eager to write about? (Jude 1:3)
choice: Their common salvation
The end times
The coming judgement
The importance of good works

question: What was Jude constrained to write about instead of his original topic? (Jude 1:3)
choice: To contend earnestly for the faith once for all delivered to the saints
To prepare for the coming of the Lord
To focus on good works
To warn them of false prophets

question: What kind of men have secretly crept in? (Jude 1:4)
choice: Ungodly men, turning the grace of God into indecency and denying Jesus Christ
Men who preach a false gospel
Those who are ignorant of the truth
Men who perform miracles

question: What does Jude remind his readers of, even though they already know it? (Jude 1:5)
choice: How the Lord saved a people out of Egypt, then destroyed those who didn't believe
The need for baptism
The importance of prayer
That Jesus is the Messiah

question: What happened to the angels who did not keep their first domain? (Jude 1:6)
choice: They are kept in everlasting bonds under darkness for the judgment of the great day
They were given authority to rule over the earth
They were banished from the presence of God
They were given a second chance

question: What is the example of Sodom and Gomorrah used to illustrate? (Jude 1:7)
choice: The punishment of eternal fire for those who give themselves over to sexual immorality
The blessings of obedience
The dangers of idolatry
The need for repentance

question: What do these ungodly men defile in their dreaming? (Jude 1:8)
choice: The flesh
The truth
The Spirit
The teachings

question: What do these ungodly men despise? (Jude 1:8)
choice: Authority
Prophecy
Good works
Love

question: What do these ungodly men slander? (Jude 1:8)
choice: Celestial beings
The Holy Spirit
The prophets
The Church

question: How did Michael the archangel respond to the devil when arguing about the body of Moses? (Jude 1:9)
choice: He said, 'May the Lord rebuke you!'
He condemned the devil
He physically fought him
He ignored the devil

question: What is the fate of those who speak evil of what they do not know? (Jude 1:10)
choice: They are destroyed
They are corrected
They are given a chance to repent
They are pitied

question: What three examples of ungodly behavior are given as a warning? (Jude 1:11)
choice: The way of Cain, the error of Balaam, and the rebellion of Korah
The way of the Pharisees, the error of the Sadducees, and the rebellion of the Zealots
The way of the scribes, the error of the priests, and the rebellion of the people
The way of the kings, the error of the prophets, and the rebellion of the judges

question: What are these ungodly men described as being in the love feasts? (Jude 1:12)
choice: Hidden rocky reefs, shepherds who feed themselves, clouds without water, autumn trees without fruit
An example to follow, humble servants, clear springs, fruitful trees
Leaders of the church, models of faith, rivers of life, trees with abundant fruit
An important part of the community, good teachers, dew-filled clouds, trees bearing much fruit

question: What are these ungodly men compared to regarding their instability? (Jude 1:13)
choice: Wild waves of the sea, foaming out their own shame; wandering stars
Strong pillars, standing firm in the truth; fixed stars
Gentle streams, flowing with peace; guiding stars
Calm waters, reflecting the glory of God; consistent stars

question: Who prophesied about the coming judgment with the Lord? (Jude 1:14)
choice: Enoch, the seventh from Adam
Noah, the tenth from Adam
Abraham, a descendant of Adam
Moses, a descendant of Adam

question: What is the purpose of the Lord's coming with ten thousands of his holy ones? (Jude 1:15)
choice: To execute judgment on all and convict the ungodly
To bring peace and reconciliation
To teach the truth and convert people
To establish his kingdom on Earth

question: What are the ungodly described as doing in the last times? (Jude 1:16)
choice: Murmurers and complainers, walking after their lusts, speaking proud things
Praying and fasting, seeking God's will
Living in holiness, following the commandments
Helping those in need, acting compassionately

question: What should believers remember? (Jude 1:17)
choice: The words spoken before by the apostles of Jesus Christ
The law of Moses
The teachings of the prophets
The examples of the patriarchs

question: What do the apostles say will happen in the last time? (Jude 1:18)
choice: Mockers will walk after their own ungodly lusts
Everyone will repent and turn to God
There will be peace and prosperity
The church will be united

question: What are those who cause divisions described as? (Jude 1:19)
choice: Sensual and not having the Spirit
Spiritual and righteous
Wise and discerning
Humble and loving

question: How should believers keep themselves in God's love? (Jude 1:20-21)
choice: By building themselves up on their most holy faith, praying in the Holy Spirit, and looking for the mercy of Jesus Christ
By strictly following the law of Moses, fasting, and giving to the poor
By isolating themselves from the world, practicing asceticism, and engaging in self-denial
By engaging in rituals, giving offerings, and relying on their own good works

question: What should believers do in response to those who are in sin? (Jude 1:22-23)
choice: Have compassion, making a distinction; save some, snatching them out of the fire with fear, hating even the clothing stained by the flesh
Judge them harshly, condemning their actions; isolate them from the community; publicly shame them
Ignore them, pretending that their sin doesn't exist; avoid them at all costs
Pretend to understand their point of view; condone their sinful acts; encourage their lifestyle
